div.p: It is scarcely possible to read the greatest of Plato’s dialogues without instituting some comparison between his doctrines and those of Christianity. That the feeling of the reader toward the Greek Philosopher is different from that with which he views the sacred writers, makes the comparison none the less natural. It is provoked as much by points of marked difference as by others of strong similarity. First among the points of likeness is the; appreciation of the moral goodness of God. The divinity of Plato is not merely a God of purity, he is also a God of goodness and truth. It is (in Plato’s opinion) impiety to refer any evils to God as their author; God is good and goodness can be the cause of nothing but good. The wicked, if chastised, must be punished for their good, ‘God is the cause not of all things but only of blessings', (Rep. 380, 381.) It is blasphemy also to ascribe untruth in word or deed to God. He is not a man that he should lie. [(Rep. 382, 383/ The false views circulated by poets of'the divine nature were a principal cause of their banishment from Plato’s commonwealth, This belief in the moral goodness of the divine character is the more remarkable when it is remembered that Aristotle denied that the Gods could possess moral virtue. On the subject of the treatment of our enemies, the doctrines of Plato approach very near to those of Christianity. If Plato did not teach that men should forgive their enemies he asserted that the good man would injure no one, for that the bad were only made worse by injury, and that a good man could not be the cause of others becoming worse, (Rep. 335.) A striking verbal resemblance between the language of Plato and of the New Testament is seen in the description of the unity of the ideal state—that “ city which is at unity with itself/’ “ That state is best governed,” says Plato, “in which as in the body, all suffers when one part suffers,” (462.) It is impossible not to be reminded of that society where, “if one member suffer all the members suffer, or whether one member be honored all the members rejoice with it.” This passage is connected with another point, where the likeness between Platonism and Christianity is something more than verbal. In the ideal state of Plato private property ceases. In his words, the best of states is that in which all men call the*same thing ° mine and not mine." (Hep. 463 ) The early history of the church also tells of a time when u neither said any one that aught of the things that he possessed were his own, but they had all things in common.” The resemblance of expression is striking; but there is more than a resmblance of expression. There is a view of Christianity which all established societies hate to contemplate, but which reappears at many crises of the world’s history. Anabaptists, Puritans, English Levellers, and many sects of modern times have felt that Christianity proclaims an equality, not in religion only but also in outward society. With tins view of Christianity, Plato’s communism has much in common. Connected with this part of Platonism, is the view of the position of woman, a subject on which Platonism and Christianity have points of resem- blance as well as points of the strongest contrast. Plato declares the equality, (except in strength) of the sexes : be therefore ordains an education for women, similar to the training prepared for his men. Christianity, though in a different spirit, proclaims the essential equality of man and woman. It tells that, in one point of view, and that the highest there is “ neither male nor female for we are all one in Christ Jesus.’*

As the Republic draws to a close, another likeness to Christianity appears. Under a form hard entirely to comprehend, is sketched the vision of a judgment to come. Platonism like Christianity looked for a day when all men should appear before the judgment seat of God to answer for the deeds done in the body. The Republic has been compared to a church. The comparison is partly fanciful ; yet the resemblance between the two is consider- able. Both are at once societies on earth, yet with aims higher than those of any mere earthly society. Both are ruled by principles different from those ruling other states. Both protest against the errors of all existing communities. Both believe (though in a different manner and degree) in a God of goodness. Both seem incomplete without a reference to a future judgement. Yet striking as are the resemblances between Platonism and Christianity, the differences are greater. Platonism is not a system for the whole world. It is essentially Greek. For a time the reader fancies that the Republic is a purely ideal state, suitable alike for every land, till he is startled by some assertion, showing how entirely national Plato’s conceptions are. That Plato’s Republic must be a Greek town is explicitly stated. A marked distinction is drawn between the treatment in war, of Greeks and Barbarians. The Republic might not inaptly be termed an idealized Sparta; the tutelary Gods of Greece are to be worshipped in it, and on many subjects Apollo is to be appealed to through his oracle. More, however, than any one assertion, the vein of Greek feeling running through the dialogue, marks the ideal city as a Greek state. Connected with this feeling are the sensuous enjoyments, utterly at variance with Christian sentiment which are offered to the citizens. Thus the brave in battle are to be rewarded with crowns, and garlands, with the permission to embrace wThom they wil1, with seats of honour, goblets of wine, and long chines of beef. If they fall they are to be worshipped as Demigods. (Rep. 409.)

But a more radical difference between the two systems appears in the fact that in Platonism all depends on the intellect: it is a gospel for those only of high mental powers. For the “ perfect character,1’* many moral qualities are required, but it is, above all, necessary that it have a readiness in learning (evftaOr'is) without this qualification any great progress in Platonism is impossible. Thht God is good is a conviction lield in common by Platonism and Christianity, yet it is perhaps when we consider the Platonic view of the Divinity that the difference between the two systems most clearly appears. The Gods of Greece are not deposed by Plato. He declares that legends injurious to their moral character are untrue, and that they must be forbidden by law. He plainly intends to retain the old forms of worship in his state. It is, nevertheless, not in his language about the Gods, that it is necessary to look for Plato’s idea of * Divinity.* Far above all his other theories, is the mysterious thought of “ the Good. *’ (rp ayador) What it is Socrates confesses he cannot describe. He can only express it under a figure, what the sun is in the world of sense that the Good is in the world of ideas. It is not truth or knowledge; it is above them, it causes them. The reader might suppose it to be a first cause, were it not that Plato speaks of it with a kind of religious enthusiasm. The whole of his philosophic training is intended to guide the soul to a contemplation of the Good; by a life long study the soul attains to a view of it. The Good has been described as God without the idea of personality. Such a notion of God which makes knowledge of the Divinity attainable by the intellect only, renders it impossible that the Divine nature should ever be known to any but the most highly gifted in mental power. The poor and the illiterate might in Plato's State enjoy many blessings, under the rule of perfectly educated philosophers; the knowledge of God was never offered them.

In another respect Christianity and Platonism are strangely contrasted. Each was fundamently opposed to the state of society around it. But this opposition was different: Plato to reform society, proposed in theory, a total revolution. Every institution of society needed reconstruction. To form his state—^-even when the philosopher should be King—it was necessary to begin •everything from the beginning : a complete system of new institu- tions was to be introduced. Christianity also was opposed to the society, in which it arose, yet it needed to produce its effects, no sudden revolution. Few of the institutions of the age, except idolatry, are specially denounced in the New Testament. It is not new forms of government so much as a new spirit, and a new belief that are required. The Republic of Plato remained a mere theoiy. Christianity revolutionized the world. Yet while acknowledging the great and essential difference between Platonism and Christianity, the mind is still impressed with their strong points of resem- blance. Though it be true that Plato's ‘‘Fair City” remains a mere Utopia, whilst Christianity is an existing fact; still in one point of view each are theories but partially carried out. If Plato's Republic still waits for its realization, till that yet distant day when tl Kings shall be philosophers or Philosophers be kings” Christianity itself, as a society, is but half realized. It too needs for its fulfilment that the Kingdoms of this world should become the Kingdoms of our Lord and of his Christ.”
